title: Does denying the existence of races make one a racist? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely not. By Western definitions (or more specifically, American), different races (white (Americans and Europeans), black (Africans or of African descent), yellow (Asians)) are just the difference in levels of melanin in people’s skin as an evolutionary survival trait due to sunlight density in different geographical locations of the planet, which are carried on to the next generations even when they live in areas where such physical traits were no longer necessary.  To draw the difference in skin colors as races would mean the difference between Homo Sapiens and Homo Erectus or the Neanderthals. Let’s be frank, we’re all Sapiens here.  In Vietnam we have many different “people”, such as the Kinh (also the majority of Vietnamese), the Dao, Thai, the Khmer (who were of Cambodian descent), etc. but they were considered as “clans” or “tribes”, never races. We treat them with dignity and respect, not some inferior species to look down upon or shun away.

I wish all of humanity would look at skin color similar to the way we look at hair or eye color. It would be wonderful if skin color were universally viewed as a matter of aesthetics, nothing more. Tragically, we assign some great undeserved importance to this thing we call race. We then weaponize it. We are not well. Since so many of us are race conscious, I guess most of us feel obliged to go along with the insanity. At least Dr. King dreamed of a day when we would become moral enough not to judge people on the basis of skin color. In the current reality, it would be stupid to utterly deny the existence of race. But, at least one can participate in the insanity grudgingly rather than enthusiastically.

I don't think so, I'd say on the contrary. The concept of race is deemed flawed in Europe, because it refers originally to the technique of breeding animals. A Jack Russel or a Dalmatian are races of dogs, which are artificially maintained by directing their breeding. As we humans breed as we wish, that can't be called races for us. The scientists talk rather of ethnies, which are physical and cultural traits shared by communities. That is deemed a better concept to apprehend the diversity of humanity. In France where I live, ironically the concept of race is used mainly by true racists and by “antiracists" who use the US “race studies” views.

We are all one race. But I have to admit to race because other people do. It's a classification I don't agree to. But society has divided us in those terms. As long as people are deemed better or worse based on skin tone, I will have to argue against both the classification and the discrimination that DOES exist. The discrimination is real. That may be why right wing Republicans believe in conspiracies. They take something that isn't real, and make it an issue: Race isn't real but racism is.

No. It is simply stating a fact. Scientifically speaking there is no such concept as race. All human beings are the same and things like skin tone and facial structures are irrelevant to the study of human beings. Race like many other things is just a barrier people put between themselves. Source: There’s No Scientific Basis for Race—It's a Made-Up Label

Not racist, just ignorant. Saying “one race, the human race" denies us of our individuality. We are one species, but made up of a number of different races. All of which are unique and different in their own right. These differences need to be acknowledged and celebrated and people need to stop trying to merge us all into one big multicultural mess.

Not inherently. But denying racism exists and denying the differences in experiences that race can cause is racist. You need to understand that other people will see race and that will cause them to have different experiences from you. Do not deny their experiences of racism just because of your specific beliefs.
